p: RVFV was first isolated in the Central African Republic (CAR) in 1969 from a pool of Mansonia africana mosquitoes [ 22]. It was identified as the causative virus of RVF in 1983 [ 23, 24]. RVFV-specific antibodies have since been detected in humans, and 15 strains of RVFV have been isolated from humans and sylvatic mosquitoes in CAR [ 25, 26], although no RVF outbreak has been reported. Current circulation of RVFV in the CAR is unknown, after a gap of two decades without surveillance; however, as animal breeding plays a large part in the economy of the CAR, an epidemic involving humans and animals is possible.
